sect1.title: Setting up NFS server with cluster scripts
sect1.para: This section describes the initial configuration of a highly available NFS export in the context of the &pace; cluster manager with &crmshell; cluster scripts. Furthermore, it is assumed that you create DRBD on empty disks (or partitions).

Cluster scripts provide an integrated way to perform common tasks across the cluster. This section uses cluster scripts extensively by performing the crm script run command. Use the verify subcommand to check your arguments before you execute it. For example, to verify the sbd primitive and its parameters, run:
sect1.screen: &prompt.root;crm script verify sbd id=sdb.&node1; node=178325803 sbd_device=/dev/sdb

sect2.title: SBD device
sect2.para: This setup uses the most simple SBD (STONITH Based Death) setup. It is appropriate for clusters where all of your data is on the same shared storage. The shared storage segment must not use host-based RAID, LVM2, nor DRBD*. See and for further details. Proceed as follows:

step.para: Determine a dedicated device or partition as SBD device.
Get the identifier of your node where this SBD device should be run:
In this case, our primary node is &node1;, so the identifier is 178325803.
Run the sbd cluster script:
step.screen: &prompt.root;crm script run sbd id=sdb.&node1; node=178325803 sbd_device=/dev/sdb

sect2.title: LVM configuration
sect2.para: To use LVM with DRBD, it is necessary to change some options in the LVM configuration file (/etc/lvm/lvm.conf) and to remove stale cache entries on the nodes. This can be done manually (see the following procedure) or use &yast;'s DRBD module. In the &yast; DRBD module, to make the automatically change inactive, disable the checkbox Modify LVM Device filter Automatically and change filter manually. In the LVM Configuration entry you can enable or disable the LVM cache.
To remove the cache manually, do the following:

step.para: Open /etc/lvm/lvm.conf on your primary node in a text editor.

Delete /etc/lvm/cache/.cache to remove any stale cache entries.
Use &csync; to replicate these changes to peer node.

sect2.title: DRBD resource
sect2.para: It is necessary to configure a DRBD resource to hold your data. This resource will act as the physical volume of an LVM volume group to be created later. This section assums that the LVM volume group is to be called nfs. Hence, the DRBD resource uses that same name.

step.para: Load the DRBD kernel module to make the proc file /proc/drbd available:

Add the following line in /etc/csync2/csync2.cfg:
Create a file /etc/dracut.conf.d/drbd.conf. The .conf extension is required, but you can freely choose the base name.
Insert your DRBD driver without the .ko extension and save the file:
Use &csync; to replicate these changes to peer node.
Build the initrd:
Reboot.
Create a DRBD resource:
step.screen: &prompt.root;crm script run drbd id=drbd drbd_resource=nfs drbdconf=/etc/drbd.d/nfs.res

sect2.title: File system resources
sect2.para: This section creates the respective file systems for sales and devel and groups them:

step.para: Create the sales file system resource:
step.screen: &prompt.root;crm script run filesystem id=fs-sales device=/dev/nfs/sales directory=/srv/nfs/sales fstype=ext3

step.para: Create the devel file system resource:
step.screen: &prompt.root;crm script run filesystem id=fs-devel device=/dev/nfs/devel directory=/srv/nfs/devel fstype=ext3

step.para: Group the LVM, sales, and devel resources:
step.screen: &prompt.root;crm configure group g-nfs lvm fs-sales fs-devel

sect2.para: After you have finished this procedure, check the resource group with crm status:

sect2.title: NFS export resources
sect2.para: After your DRBD, LVM, and file system resources are working properly, continue with the resources managing your NFS exports. To create highly available NFS export resources, use the exportfs resource type.

step.para: If clients exclusively use NFSv3 to connect to the server, you do not need this resource. In this case, continue with , otherwise proceed:
Create the root of the virtual NFSv4 file system:
step.remark: toms 2015-10-26: How do you derive clientspec?
step.screen: &prompt.root;crm script run exportfs id=exportfs-root directory=/srv/nfs options="rw,crossmnt" clientspec="10.161.60.0/255.255.255.0" fsid=0

step.para: Clone the resource:

This resource does not hold any actual NFS-exported data, merely the empty directory (/srv/nfs) that the other NFS exports are mounted into. Since there is no shared data involved here, we can safely clone this resource.
Since any data should be exported only on nodes where this clone has been properly started, add the following constraints to the configuration:
step.screen: &prompt.root;crm order o-root_before_nfs Mandatory: cl-exportfs-root g-nfs:start &prompt.root;crm colocation c-nfs_on_root inf: g-nfs cl-exportfs-root

step.para: Check the output of the exportfs -v command to verify this.
Create NFS exports for sales and develop:
step.screen: &prompt.root;crm script run exportfs id=export-sales directory=/srv/nfs/sales/ \ options="rw,mountpoint" clientspec="10.161.60.0/255.255.255.0" fsid=1 &prompt.root;crm script run exportfs id=export-devel directory=/srv/nfs/devel/ \ options="rw,mountpoint" clientspec="10.161.60.0/255.255.255.0" fsid=2

step.para: After you have created these resources, add them to the existing g-nfs resource group:
It should look like this:
step.screen: group g-nfs lvm fs-sales fs-devel exportfs-sales exportfs-devel

sect2.para: After you have finished this procedures, exportfs -v gives you this result:

sect2.title: Resource for floating IP address
sect2.para: To enable smooth and seamless failover, your NFS clients will be connecting to the NFS service via a floating cluster IP address, rather than via any of the hosts' physical IP addresses.

step.para: Create a virtual, floating IPv4 address:
step.screen: &prompt.root;crm script run virtual-ip id=vip-nfs ip=10.9.9.180 cidr_netmask=24

step.para: Add the IP address to the resource group (like you did with the exportfs resources):
This is the final setup of the resource group:
step.screen: group g-nfs \ lvm fs-devel fs-sales \ exportfs-devel exportfs-sales \ vip-nfs

sect2.para: Confirm that the cluster IP is running correctly:
The cluster IP should be added as a secondary address to whatever interface is connected to the 10.9.9.0/24 subnet.
